articles.title: Astronomers detect life’s building blocks around a young star
articles.summary: Astronomers using ALMA have discovered complex organic molecules, including potential precursors to life's building blocks, in the protoplanetary disc of a young star, V883 Orionis. This finding offers a tantalizing glimpse into how life-friendly chemistry may be far more widespread and inherited than previously thought.
articles.content:
Using the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), a team of astronomers led by Abubakar Fadul from the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy (MPIA) has discovered complex organic molecules - including the first tentative detection of ethylene glycol and glycolonitrile - in the protoplanetary disc of the outbursting protostar V883 Orionis. These compounds are considered precursors to the building blocks of life. Comparing different cosmic environments reveals that the abundance and complexity of such molecules increase from star-forming regions to fully evolved planetary systems. This suggests that the seeds of life are assembled in space and are widespread. The findings were published in the Astrophysical Journal Letters today.

Astronomers have discovered complex organic molecules (COMs) in various locations associated with planet and star formation before. COMs are molecules with more than five atoms, at least one of which is carbon. Many of them are considered building blocks of life, such as amino acids and nucleic acids or their precursors. The discovery of 17 COMs in the protoplanetary disc of V883 Orionis, including ethylene glycol and glycolonitrile, provides a long-sought puzzle piece in the evolution of such molecules between the stages preceding and following the formation of stars and their planet-forming discs. Glycolonitrile is a precursor of the amino acids glycine and alanine, as well as the nucleobase adenine.

The assembly of prebiotic molecules begins in interstellar space

"Our finding points to a straight line of chemical enrichment and increasing complexity between interstellar clouds and fully evolved planetary systems," said Abubakar Fadul, MPIA

The transition from a cold protostar to a young star surrounded by a disc of dust and gas is accompanied by a violent phase of shocked gas, intense radiation and rapid gas ejection.

Such energetic processes might destroy most of the complex chemistry assembled during the previous stages. Therefore, scientists had laid out a so-called 'reset' scenario, in which most of the chemical compounds required to evolve into life would have to be reproduced in circumstellar discs while forming comets, asteroids, and planets.

"Now it appears the opposite is true," MPIA scientist and co-author Kamber Schwarz points out. "Our results suggest that protoplanetary discs inherit complex molecules from earlier stages, and the formation of complex molecules can continue during the protoplanetary disc stage." Indeed, the period between the energetic protostellar phase and the establishment of a protoplanetary disk would, on its own, be too short for COMs to form in detectable amounts.

As a result, the conditions that predefine biological processes may be widespread rather than being restricted to individual planetary systems.

Astronomers have found the simplest organic molecules, such as methanol, in dense regions of dust and gas that predate the formation of stars. Under favourable conditions, they may even contain complex compounds comprising ethylene glycol, one of the species now discovered in V883 Orionis. "We recently found ethylene glycol could form by UV irradiation of ethanolamine, a molecule that was recently discovered in space," adds Tushar Suhasaria, a co-author and the head of MPIA's Origins of Life Lab. "This finding supports the idea that ethylene glycol could form in those environments but also in later stages of molecular evolution, where UV irradiation is dominant."

More evolved agents crucial to biology, such as amino acids, sugars, and nucleobases that make up DNA and RNA, are present in asteroids, meteorites, and comets within the Solar System.

Buried in ice - resurfaced by stars

The chemical reactions that synthesize those COMs occur under cold conditions, preferably on icy dust grains that later coagulate to form larger objects. Hidden in those mixtures of rock, dust, and ice, they usually remain undetected. Accessing those molecules is only possible either by digging for them with space probes or by external heating, which evaporates the ice.

In the Solar System, the Sun heats comets, resulting in impressive tails of gas and dust, or comas, essentially gaseous envelopes that surround the cometary nuclei. This way, spectroscopy - the rainbow-like dissection of light - may pick up the emissions of freed molecules. Those spectral fingerprints help astronomers to identify the molecules previously buried in ice.

A similar heating process is occurring in the V883 Orionis system. The central star is still growing by accumulating gas from the surrounding disc until it eventually ignites the fusion fire in its core. During those growth periods, the infalling gas heats up and produces intense outbursts of radiation. "These outbursts are strong enough to heat the surrounding disc as far as otherwise icy environments, releasing the chemicals we have detected," explains Fadul.

"Complex molecules, including ethylene glycol and glycolonitrile, radiate at radio frequencies. ALMA is perfectly suited to detect those signals," says Schwarz. The MPIA astronomers were awarded access to this radio interferometer through the European Southern Observatory (ESO), which operates it in the Chilean Atacama Desert at an altitude of 5,000 metres. ALMA enabled the astronomers to pinpoint the V883 Orionis system and search for faint spectral signatures, which ultimately led to the detections.

Further challenges ahead

"While this result is exciting, we still haven't disentangled all the signatures we found in our spectra," says Schwarz. "Higher resolution data will confirm the detections of ethylene glycol and glycolonitril and maybe even reveal more complex chemicals we simply haven't identified yet."

"Perhaps we also need to look at other regions of the electromagnetic spectrum to find even more evolved molecules," Fadul points out. "Who knows what else we might discover?"

Additional information

The MPIA team involved in this study comprised Abubakar Fadul, Kamber Schwarz, and Tushar Suhasaria.

Other researchers were Jenny K. Calahan (Center for Astrophysics -- Harvard & Smithsonian, Cambridge, USA), Jane Huang (Department of Astronomy, Columbia University, New York, USA), and Merel L. R. van 't Hoff (Department of Physics and Astronomy, Purdue University, West Lafayette, USA).

The Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), an international astronomy facility, is a partnership of the European Southern Observatory (ESO), the U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) and the National Institutes of Natural Sciences (NINS) of Japan in cooperation with the Republic of Chile. ALMA is funded by ESO on behalf of its Member States, by NSF in cooperation with the National Research Council of Canada (NRC) and the National Science and Technology Council (NSTC) in Taiwan and by NINS in cooperation with the Academia Sinica (AS) in Taiwan and the Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute (KASI). ALMA construction and operations are led by ESO on behalf of its Member States; by the National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO), managed by Associated Universities, Inc. (AUI), on behalf of North America; and by the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ) on behalf of East Asia. The Joint ALMA Observatory (JAO) provides the unified leadership and management of the construction, commissioning, and operation of ALMA.

articles.personality_title: Astronomers find key life-related molecules near young star
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study how life’s chemical ingredients form in space, especially around young stars where planets begin to develop. Understanding these molecules helps explain how life’s building blocks might start beyond Earth.

**What happened** – Using the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile, astronomers led by Abubakar Fadul from the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy found complex organic molecules in the dusty disc around a young star called V883 Orionis. They detected 17 such molecules, including ethylene glycol and glycolonitrile, which are important precursors to amino acids and nucleobases—key parts of proteins and DNA.

**Impact** – This is the first time these specific molecules were seen in the planet-forming disc of a young star during an energetic phase. It shows that important chemical ingredients for life can survive harsh conditions and may be widespread in space. The discovery helps connect the dots between molecules found in interstellar clouds and those in mature planetary systems.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue observing other young stars and their discs to see if similar molecules are common. This could improve our understanding of the early chemical steps that lead to life on planets, possibly guiding future studies about the origins of life beyond Earth.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have detected complex molecules linked to life’s origins around a young star, revealing that these life-related chemicals may form and persist early in planet formation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des astronomes détectent des molécules clés liées à la vie autour d’une jeune étoile
articles.personality_presentation_fr:

Comprendre ces molécules aide à expliquer comment les briques de la vie peuvent apparaître au-delà de la Terre.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Grâce à l’Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) au Chili, des astronomes dirigés par Abubakar Fadul de l’Institut Max Planck d’astronomie ont découvert des molécules organiques complexes dans le disque de poussière entourant une jeune étoile appelée V883 Orionis. Ils ont détecté 17 molécules, dont le glycol éthylique et le glycolonitrile, des précurseurs importants des acides aminés et des bases azotées, composants essentiels des protéines et de l’ADN.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que ces molécules spécifiques sont observées dans un disque formant des planètes autour d’une jeune étoile pendant une phase énergétique. Cela montre que ces ingrédients chimiques essentiels à la vie peuvent survivre à des conditions difficiles et sont probablement répandus dans l’espace. articles.title: Ghost star’s planet orbits backward in a bizarre stellar system
articles.summary: A bizarre planet defies cosmic norms: scientists have confirmed a giant planet orbiting in reverse around one star in a close binary system—an arrangement previously thought impossible. Using advanced tools, they discovered the companion star is a faint white dwarf that lost most of its mass billions of years ago. The team now believes this planet may be a rare second-generation world, born from or captured by the debris of its dying stellar neighbor. This find challenges traditional models of planet formation and opens a new chapter in exoplanetary science.
articles.content:
Most stars in the Universe exist in binary or multiple star systems, where the presence of close-in companion stars in such systems can adversely influence the formation and orbital stability of planets around one of the stars. An international team of astrophysicists led by Professor Man Hoi LEE from the Department of Earth Sciences and the Department of Physics at The University of Hong Kong (HKU) and Mr Ho Wan Cheng, an MPhil student in his team, has confirmed the existence of a planet in an unprecedented retrograde orbit (moving in the opposite direction to the binary’s orbit) in the nu Octantis (nu Octantis) binary star system and revealed the role of binary star evolution in the origin of this planet. The findings have been published in the journal Nature.

nu Octantis is a tight binary star system comprising a primary subgiant star, nu Oct A, with about 1.6 times the mass of the Sun, and a secondary star, nu Oct B, with about half the mass of the Sun. The two stars orbit each other with a period of 1,050 days.



An additional periodic signal in the radial velocity observations (measurements of how a star moves towards or away from us) of this system was first reported by Dr David Ramm, a co-author of this new paper, during his PhD studies at the University of Canterbury, New Zealand, in 2004. This signal was consistent with the presence of a Jovian planet of about twice the mass of Jupiter orbiting around the primary star, nu Oct A, with a period of about 400 days. However, the existence of this planet has been controversial because its orbit would be so wide that it could only remain stable if it were retrograde and moved in the opposite direction to the orbit of the binary. There were no observational precedents for such a planet and strong theoretical grounds against its formation.



To settle the debate, the research team obtained new high-precision radial velocity observations using the European Southern Observatory (ESO)’s HARPS spectrograph, which confirmed the existence of the planet signal. “We performed an analysis of the new and archival radial velocity data spanning 18 years and found stable fits that require the planetary orbit to be retrograde and nearly in the same plane as the binary orbit,” said Mr Ho Wan Cheng, the first author of the paper.



Another key focus of the new study was the determination of the nature of the secondary star nu Oct B. The mass of nu Oct B suggests that it could be either a low-mass main-sequence star or a white dwarf. All stars spend most of their lives on the main sequence, generating energy through nuclear fusion of hydrogen to helium in their core. After a star has exhausted its nuclear fuel, its core collapses into a stellar remnant, which would be a white dwarf if the star’s initial mass is less than several times that of the Sun. A white dwarf has a mass comparable to that of the Sun packed in an Earth-sized volume.



To identify which type of star nu Oct B is, the research team used the adaptive optics imaging instrument SPHERE at ESO’s Very Large Telescope to observe the system. The fact that nu Oct B was not detected in these observations indicated that it must be a very faint white dwarf. This suggests that the binary system has evolved significantly since its formation, as nu Oct B has already ejected most of its mass and entered the final stage of its stellar evolution.



The research team looked into the possible primordial configurations of the binary — that is, the initial masses of the two stars and the initial orbit of the binary. “We found that the system is about 2.9 billion years old and that nu Oct B was initially about 2.4 times the mass of the Sun and evolved to a white dwarf about 2 billion years ago,” said Cheng. “Our analysis showed that the planet could not have formed around nu Oct A at the same time as the stars.”



The discovery that nu Oct B is a white dwarf opens new possibilities for how the retrograde planet may have originated. “When nu Oct B evolved into a white dwarf about 2 billion years ago, the planet could have formed in a retrograde disc of material around nu Oct A accreted from the mass ejected by nu Oct B, or it could be captured from a prograde orbit around the binary into a retrograde orbit around nu Oct A,” explained Professor Man Hoi LEE.



“We might be witnessing the first compelling case of a second-generation planet; either captured, or formed from material expelled by nu Oct B, which lost more than 75% of its primordial mass to become a white dwarf,” added Dr Trifon TRIFONOV of Zentrum für Astronomie der Universität Heidelberg in Germany and Sofia University St. Kliment Ohridski in Bulgaria and a co-author of the paper.



“The key to this exciting discovery was the use of several complementary methods to characterise the system in its entirety,” said PD Dr Sabine REFFERT of Zentrum für Astronomie der Universität Heidelberg and another co-author of the paper.



As astronomers continue to search for planets in different environments, this study highlights that planets in tight binary systems with evolved stellar components could offer unique insights into the formation and evolution of planets.



This research uses two facilities operated by the European Southern Observatory (ESO), namely the High Accuracy Radial Velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) spectrograph at the ESO La Silla 3.6-metre telescope and the Spectro-Polarimetric High-contrast Exoplanet Research (SPHERE) instrument at the Very Large Telescope.

articles.personality_title: Scientists confirm a planet orbiting backward in a rare binary star system
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Most stars in the universe are part of binary systems, where two stars orbit each other closely. These systems typically make planet formation and stable orbits difficult, especially for planets orbiting one star within the pair.

**What happened** – An international research team led by experts from the University of Hong Kong confirmed a giant planet orbiting in reverse—backward compared to the stars’ orbit—in the nu Octantis binary star system. This system includes two stars: a primary larger star and a smaller companion that turned into a faint white dwarf after losing much of its mass billions of years ago. Using precise radial velocity measurements from the European Southern Observatory’s HARPS instrument, the team verified the planet’s unusual orbit.

**Impact** – This discovery is unique because it challenges previous ideas that such backward orbits around one star in a close binary system were impossible. It suggests this planet might be a rare second-generation world, formed or captured from leftover material after the companion star’s transformation into a white dwarf. This changes how scientists think about planet formation in complex stellar environments.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue observing this system and others like it to better understand how planets can form and survive in binary star systems, especially under unusual conditions like backward orbits. This may lead to new models explaining the origins of such planets and guide future discoveries.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A giant planet orbiting backward around one star in a binary system challenges old ideas and reveals new possibilities for how planets can form and exist in complex star systems.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques confirment une planète en orbite rétrograde dans un système d’étoiles binaire rare
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La plupart des étoiles de l’univers font partie de systèmes binaires, où deux étoiles tournent l’une autour de l’autre. Ces systèmes rendent généralement difficile la formation et la stabilité des planètes autour d’une étoile du couple.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe internationale dirigée par des experts de l’Université de Hong Kong a confirmé l’existence d’une planète géante en orbite rétrograde — c’est-à-dire dans le sens inverse de l’orbite des étoiles — dans le système binaire nu Octantis. Ce système comprend deux étoiles : une étoile principale plus grande et une étoile secondaire plus petite devenue une naine blanche après avoir perdu la majeure partie de sa masse il y a des milliards d’années. Grâce à des mesures précises de la vitesse radiale avec l’instrument HARPS de l’Observatoire européen austral, l’équipe a confirmé l’orbite inhabituelle de la planète.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est unique car elle remet en question l’idée selon laquelle de telles orbites rétrogrades autour d’une étoile dans un système binaire proche étaient impossibles. Elle suggère que cette planète pourrait être un monde de seconde génération, formé ou capturé à partir des débris laissés après la transformation de l’étoile compagne en naine blanche. Cela modifie la compréhension scientifique de la formation planétaire dans des environnements stellaires complexes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont continuer à observer ce système et d’autres similaires pour mieux comprendre comment les planètes peuvent se former et survivre dans des systèmes binaires, notamment dans des conditions inhabituelles comme les orbites rétrogrades. Cela pourrait permettre de développer de nouveaux modèles expliquant l’origine de ces planètes et orienter de futures découvertes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une planète géante en orbite rétrograde autour d’une étoile binaire remet en cause les anciennes idées et ouvre de nouvelles possibilités sur la formation et l’existence des planètes dans des systèmes stellaires complexes.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos confirman un planeta que orbita al revés en un raro sistema binario de estrellas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La mayoría de las estrellas en el universo forman sistemas binarios, donde dos estrellas orbitan alrededor de un centro común. Estos sistemas suelen dificultar la formación y estabilidad de planetas alrededor de una de las estrellas.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo internacional liderado por expertos de la Universidad de Hong Kong confirmó la existencia de un planeta gigante orbitando en sentido contrario — es decir, en dirección opuesta a la órbita de las estrellas — en el sistema binario nu Octantis. Este sistema incluye una estrella principal más grande y una compañera más pequeña que perdió gran parte de su masa hace miles de millones de años y se convirtió en una enana blanca. Usando mediciones precisas de velocidad radial con el instrumento HARPS del Observatorio Europeo Austral, el equipo verificó la órbita inusual del planeta.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es único porque desafía la idea previa de que órbitas retrógradas en una estrella de un sistema binario cercano eran imposibles. Sugiere que este planeta podría ser un mundo de segunda generación, formado o capturado de los restos dejados tras la transformación de la estrella compañera en enana blanca. Esto cambia la comprensión científica sobre la formación de planetas en entornos estelares complejos.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán observando este sistema y otros similares para entender mejor cómo se forman y sobreviven los planetas en sistemas binarios, especialmente bajo condiciones inusuales como órbitas retrógradas. Esto podría llevar a nuevos modelos que expliquen el origen de tales planetas y guíen futuros descubrimientos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un planeta gigante que orbita en sentido contrario en un sistema binario desafía viejas ideas y muestra nuevas posibilidades para la formación y existencia de planetas en sistemas estelares complejos.

articles.title: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe finds hidden barrier that explains the sun’s mysterious heat
articles.summary: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe has flown closer to the Sun than ever before, offering the first direct glimpse into the turbulent solar atmosphere. Scientists have discovered that a phenomenon called the “helicity barrier” disrupts the way energy is transformed into heat, solving a major puzzle in how the Sun’s corona gets so hot and the solar wind accelerates. This breakthrough helps explain why solar wind protons are hotter than electrons and may also reveal how energy dissipates in other distant cosmic plasmas.
articles.content:
The solar atmosphere, or corona, is far hotter than the Sun's surface, a paradox that has puzzled scientists for decades. Furthermore, the constant outflow of plasma and magnetic fields from the Sun, known as the solar wind, is accelerated to incredible speeds. Turbulent dissipation - the process by which mechanical energy is converted into heat - is believed to play a crucial role in both these phenomena. However, in the near-Sun environment, where plasma is largely collisionless, the exact mechanisms of this dissipation have remained elusive.

This new study leverages data from NASA's Parker Solar Probe, which has become the closest spacecraft to the Sun, flying directly through the solar atmosphere. This unprecedented proximity allowed researchers to directly explore this extreme environment for the first time, providing critical data to unravel these mysteries.

The paper presents compelling evidence that the "helicity barrier" is active and profoundly alters the nature of turbulent dissipation. This effect, previously theorized, creates a barrier to the turbulent cascade of energy at small scales, fundamentally changing how fluctuations dissipate and thus how the plasma is heated.

Jack McIntyre, PhD student and the lead author of the study from Queen Mary University of London, commented: "This result is exciting because, by confirming the presence of the 'helicity barrier', we can account for properties of the solar wind that were previously unexplained, including that its protons are typically hotter than its electrons. By improving our understanding of turbulent dissipation, it could also have important implications for other systems in astrophysics."

The research team also identified the specific conditions under which this barrier occurs. They found that the helicity barrier becomes fully developed when the magnetic field strength becomes large compared to the pressure in the plasma and becomes increasingly prominent when the imbalance between the oppositely propagating plasma waves that make up the turbulence is greater. Critically, these conditions are frequently met in the solar wind close to the Sun, where Parker Solar Probe is now exploring, meaning that this effect should be widespread.

Dr Christopher Chen, Reader in Space Plasma Physics at Queen Mary University of London and McIntyre's supervisor, added: "This paper is important as it provides clear evidence for the presence of the helicity barrier, which answers some long-standing questions about coronal heating and solar wind acceleration, such as the temperature signatures seen in the solar atmosphere, and the variability of different solar wind streams. This allows us to better understand the fundamental physics of turbulent dissipation, the connection between small-scale physics and the global properties of the heliosphere, and make better predictions for space weather."

The implications of this discovery extend beyond our own star, as many hot, diffuse astrophysical plasmas in the universe are also collisionless. Understanding how energy dissipates into heat in these environments has broad consequences for astrophysics. The direct observation of the helicity barrier in the solar wind provides a unique natural laboratory to study these complex processes.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant scientific breakthrough by NASA's Parker Solar Probe that solves a longstanding mystery about the Sun's corona heating and solar wind acceleration. This discovery advances our understanding of space physics and has broader implications for cosmic plasma energy dissipation, which is inspiring and intellectually uplifting.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe explains why the Sun’s atmosphere is so hot
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long puzzled over why the Sun’s outer atmosphere, called the corona, is much hotter than its surface. They also wanted to understand how the solar wind, a stream of charged particles from the Sun, speeds up to high velocities. The key process thought to cause this heating and acceleration is called turbulent dissipation, but exactly how this happens near the Sun remained unclear.

**What happened** – NASA’s Parker Solar Probe flew closer to the Sun than any spacecraft before, entering its turbulent atmosphere. Using data from this mission, scientists discovered a phenomenon called the “helicity barrier.” This barrier changes how energy moves and turns into heat in the solar plasma. The finding explains why protons in the solar wind are hotter than electrons and sheds light on how energy dissipates in this extreme environment.

**Impact** – This discovery solves a decades-old mystery about the Sun’s corona temperature and the solar wind’s acceleration. It also confirms a theory about how the helicity barrier blocks the flow of energy at small scales, altering plasma heating. This new understanding can help explain energy processes in other cosmic plasmas, improving our knowledge of space physics.

**What's next step** – Researchers will use this insight to study other astrophysical plasmas, where similar energy dissipation might occur. Further analysis of Parker Solar Probe data will refine how the helicity barrier works under different solar conditions and may improve space weather forecasting.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s Parker Solar Probe revealed the helicity barrier, a key factor explaining the Sun’s hot atmosphere and fast solar wind by changing how energy turns into heat.
articles.personality_title_fr: La sonde Parker de la NASA explique pourquoi l’atmosphère du Soleil est si chaude
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques se sont longtemps interrogés sur la raison pour laquelle l’atmosphère externe du Soleil, appelée la couronne, est bien plus chaude que sa surface. Ils voulaient aussi comprendre comment le vent solaire, un flux de particules chargées venant du Soleil, accélère à grande vitesse. Le processus clé supposé provoquer ce chauffage et cette accélération est la dissipation turbulente, mais son fonctionnement proche du Soleil restait inconnu.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La sonde Parker de la NASA s’est approchée du Soleil plus près que tout autre engin avant elle, entrant dans son atmosphère turbulente. Grâce aux données de cette mission, les scientifiques ont découvert un phénomène appelé « barrière d’hélicité ». Cette barrière modifie la façon dont l’énergie circule et se transforme en chaleur dans le plasma solaire. Cette découverte explique pourquoi les protons du vent solaire sont plus chauds que les électrons et éclaire le processus de dissipation d’énergie dans cet environnement extrême.

**Impact** – Cette découverte résout un mystère vieux de plusieurs décennies concernant la température de la couronne solaire et l’accélération du vent solaire. Elle confirme aussi une théorie selon laquelle la barrière d’hélicité bloque le transfert d’énergie à petites échelles, modifiant ainsi le chauffage du plasma. Cette meilleure compréhension peut aider à expliquer les processus énergétiques dans d’autres plasmas cosmiques, enrichissant nos connaissances en physique spatiale.

**Étape suivante** – Les chercheurs utiliseront cette découverte pour étudier d’autres plasmas astrophysiques où une dissipation d’énergie similaire pourrait avoir lieu. Une analyse plus poussée des données de la sonde Parker affinera la compréhension du rôle de la barrière d’hélicité dans diverses conditions solaires et pourrait améliorer la prévision du climat spatial.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La sonde Parker de la NASA a révélé la barrière d’hélicité, un élément clé expliquant l’atmosphère chaude du Soleil et la vitesse élevée du vent solaire en modifiant la conversion de l’énergie en chaleur.
articles.personality_title_es: La sonda Parker de la NASA explica por qué la atmósfera del Sol es tan caliente
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante mucho tiempo, los científicos se han preguntado por qué la atmósfera externa del Sol, llamada corona, es mucho más caliente que su superficie. También querían entender cómo el viento solar, un flujo de partículas cargadas del Sol, se acelera a altas velocidades. Se cree que el proceso clave que causa este calentamiento y aceleración es la disipación turbulenta, pero cómo ocurre cerca del Sol no estaba claro.

**Qué pasó** – La sonda Parker de la NASA voló más cerca del Sol que cualquier otra nave, entrando en su atmósfera turbulenta. Con datos de esta misión, los científicos descubrieron un fenómeno llamado “barrera de helicidad”. Esta barrera cambia cómo la energía se mueve y se convierte en calor en el plasma solar. Este hallazgo explica por qué los protones del viento solar están más calientes que los electrones y aclara cómo se disipa la energía en este ambiente extremo.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento resuelve un misterio que llevaba décadas sobre la temperatura de la corona solar y la aceleración del viento solar. Confirma una teoría sobre cómo la barrera de helicidad bloquea el flujo de energía a pequeña escala, cambiando el calentamiento del plasma. Este nuevo entendimiento puede ayudar a explicar procesos energéticos en otros plasmas cósmicos, mejorando nuestro conocimiento de la física espacial.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores usarán este conocimiento para estudiar otros plasmas astrofísicos donde podría ocurrir una disipación similar de energía. Un análisis más detallado de los datos de la sonda Parker ayudará a entender mejor cómo funciona la barrera de helicidad en diferentes condiciones solares y podría mejorar la predicción del clima espacial.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La sonda Parker de la NASA descubrió la barrera de helicidad, un factor clave que explica la atmósfera caliente del Sol y el rápido viento solar al cambiar cómo la energía se convierte en calor.

articles.title: SpaceX 'Crew Dragon' docks with ISS just 15 hours after launch
articles.summary: A SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule carrying an international team of four astronauts docked on Saturday with the orbiting International Space Station (ISS) just 15 hours after it launched.
articles.content:
Crew-11 mission astronauts pause outside the Neil A. Armstrong Operations and Checkout Building en route to launch complex LC-39A at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Florida on August 1, 2025

The four US, Russian and Japanese astronauts pulled up in their SpaceX capsule just 15 hours after launching from NASA's Kennedy Space Center.

"Docking confirmed!", SpaceX posted on social media, along with a video showing the spacecraft making contact with the ISS at 2:27am Eastern Time (0627 GMT), far above the southeast Pacific Ocean.

American astronauts Zena Cardman and Mike Fincke, Japan's Kimiya Yui, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Oleg Platonov are joining the ISS on a six-month mission at the orbiting lab, swapping places with colleagues up there since March.

They lifted off Friday morning from Kennedy Space Center in Florida, their capsule mounted on a Falcon 9 rocket.

It is the 11th crew rotation mission to the ISS under NASA's Commercial Crew Program, created to succeed the Space Shuttle era by partnering with private industry.

"We have cold drinks, hot food, and us waiting – see you soon," the ISS crew told the new arrivals shortly after contact, according to the posted video.

"Hello Space Station – Crew 11 is here and we are super excited to join," Fincke replied.

As part of their stay, the Crew-11 astronauts will simulate Moon landing scenarios that could be encountered near the lunar South Pole under the US-led Artemis program.

Using handheld controllers and multiple display screens, they will test how shifts in gravity affect astronauts' ability to pilot spacecraft, including future lunar landers.

Continuously inhabited since 2000, the ISS functions as a testbed for research that supports deeper space exploration -- including eventual missions to Mars.

Among Crew-11's more colorful cargo items are Armenian pomegranate seeds, which will be compared to a control batch kept on Earth to study how microgravity influences crop growth.

The ISS is set to be decommissioned after 2030, with its orbit gradually lowered until it breaks up in the atmosphere over a remote part of the Pacific Ocean called Point Nemo, a spacecraft graveyard.

(FRANCE 24 with AFP and AP)

articles.personality_title_es: SpaceX Crew Dragon se acopla a la EEI solo 15 horas después del lanzamiento
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La Estación Espacial Internacional (EEI) es un laboratorio en órbita alrededor de la Tierra, habitada continuamente desde 2000. El Programa Comercial de Tripulación de la NASA trabaja con empresas privadas para enviar astronautas a la EEI, reemplazando las misiones del Transbordador Espacial.

**Qué pasó**
El 1 de agosto de 2025, una cápsula SpaceX Crew Dragon con cuatro astronautas de EE.UU., Rusia y Japón despegó desde el Centro Espacial Kennedy de la NASA en Florida. Apenas 15 horas después, la cápsula se acopló con éxito a la EEI. Los astronautas—Zena Cardman, Mike Fincke, Kimiya Yui y Oleg Platonov—se unieron a la estación para una misión de seis meses.

**Impacto**
El rápido acoplamiento muestra que los viajes espaciales son cada vez más eficientes, gracias a la colaboración entre la NASA y empresas privadas como SpaceX. Esta misión apoya investigaciones clave para futuras exploraciones a la Luna y Marte. El equipo internacional refleja la cooperación entre países para avanzar en la ciencia espacial.

**Próximo paso**
Durante su estancia, los astronautas simularán escenarios de aterrizaje lunar, evaluando cómo los cambios de gravedad afectan el control de las naves. También estudiarán el crecimiento de semillas de granada armenia en microgravedad, para entender mejor el cultivo de alimentos en el espacio.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Una cápsula SpaceX Crew Dragon se acopló a la EEI solo 15 horas después del lanzamiento, marcando un paso rápido y exitoso en misiones espaciales internacionales y planes futuros de exploración.
